data.text: Flat Pedals for Long Distance Bicycle Touring

Looking for recommendation for flat pedals for long distance (100-200km) mixed terrain rides. Thinking of switching away from clipless for more flexibility both in terms of footwear on long distance rides (trainers/sandals) and the ability to hop on my bike to go into town more easily. Not really interested in single sided SPDs or the platforms you can clip into them. Need to be grippy for offroad and comfortable for long distance.

I'm using something that looks like these, but I don't recall them being that costly... https://www.bikester.co.uk/shimano-saint-pd-m828-pedals-M459079.html?cgid=36934
Shimano Saint PD-M828 Pedals | Bikester.co.uk
bikester.co.uk
data.author: Peter Walker

data.text: I've got something similar that was cheap off amazon, I've never used the clipped ones, think I'd die ,üòÇ
data.author: Mike Creighton

data.text: I'm worried about this the other way now ü§£ been riding clipless so long.
data.author: Jo Boj

data.text: üòÇ I can't get my head around getting me feet off in timeüòÇ I've had no issues with flat pedals, mine have little lugs on top which give more than enough grip, just watch they don't smack you in the shins üòÇ
data.author: Mike Creighton

data.text: Probably the price of a good pedal these days. Also been recommended Burgtec and Hope on a different group at similar and a bit more.
data.author: Jo Boj

data.text: I used clipless briefly, but I had a couple of tumbles when things went wrong, and I'm such a slow cyclist that I would never have benefitted from pulling up as well as pushing down on the pedals. Once I stopped clipping in, I found that the arthritis in my left ankle suddenly got a lot better as well.
data.author: Peter Walker

data.text: Hope f20
data.author: Wayne Coombs

data.text: DMR V8s do me just fine. Meetlocks are a bargain brand on Amazon, but again no problems with them (though bearings are not adjustable if they get stiff)
data.author: James Hubbard

data.text:
I've got meetlocks on my gravel bike. Done thousands of mikes on them in all conditions. Like all platform pedals with studs vicious if you get hit on the shin, but wide, comfortable, durable, light, spin well (low friction), cheap https://www.amazon.co.uk/MEETLOCKS-bicycle-Aluminum-Machined-bearings/dp/B01DD9YKMS/ref=sr_1_4?crid=1UFD4EDJQ0SB&keywords=pedal+cycle+meetlock&qid=1651247567&sprefix=pedal+cycle+meetlock%2Caps%2C91&sr=8-4
MEETLOCKS Bike Pedal, CNC Machined Aluminum Alloy Body Cr-Mo 9/16" Screw Thread Spindle,3Pcs Sealed bearings,MTB BMX Cycling Bicycle Pedals
amazon.co.uk
data.author: Jon Shaw

data.text: Same here - for the cost, they were amazing!
data.author: James Hubbard

data.text: Toe clips and straps still work when set up correctly
data.author: Mark Connelly

data.text: DMR V8 and V12 are the house favourites here, V12 probably a little more comfortable
data.author: Bikepacking & Cycle Touring UK

data.text:
I use the half clip/half flat style so best if both worlds..... Works great for distance and more of road/gravel..... Check them out in my latest upload if you're interested.... https://youtu.be/XGiuNevwNKA
Solo Bikepacking John O'Groats to Land's End | JOGLE | Cairngorms to Pitlochry | Day 4
youtube.com
data.author: Roadypacking

data.text: I use DMR v12
data.author: James Aust

data.text: Used DMR 12‚Äôs for years. You can always get cheap copies from Wellgo
data.author: Chris Goodban

data.text: Pretty much any metal pedal with replaceable screws is my preference. Even better when the screws are replaced from the underside rather than the top face (if you damage the pin you can still replace them..) I'd generally rather a sealed bearing, but cup and cone work fine enough. I just buy second hand ones.. hardly any point buying new in my experience.
data.author: Sigrid Identitee

data.author: Daniel Storey

data.text: I had DMR v12 on my gravel bike, and still got them on my hardtail. I've only swapped to Boardman hybrids on the gravel bike to have the option of clipping in or flats. As for the V12s, great. Very grippy, just ask my shins and serviceable too.
data.author: Steven John Holt

data.text: I tried DMRs and loved them but bearings deteriorated quickly and switched to Shimano Saints. Also use one sided clip in (spd) touring flats a lot.
data.author: Gavin Kaizen Nicholas

data.text: I got new pedals from Woodson's in Stockport a wee while ago which had reasonable grip on them but also bought additional toe clips and the straps which I can get my feet out of very quickly but its a second or two of fiddlyness getting them in. Straps are dead easy to remove. I can't remember the brand of the pedals and toe clips/strap combo but will have a look over the weekend to see if I can find it and add to here
data.author: Andrew Forbes

data.text: thanks, but I'm not interested in (clips and) straps. I use the restrap ones on my fixie which I find good for braking and holding my feet in when descending but think the up stroke is a bit of a myth on freewheel bikes.
data.author: Jo Boj

data.text: different strokes for different folks I guess but I feel a difference in my pace when I utilise the upstroke too. I'll still check out the name of the pedals tomorrow as I bought them separate from the clips and straps just in case. I'm sure there are far more technical products mentioned on here already though
data.author: Andrew Forbes
